67 [Ypolyt]
SEint ypolyt þe Martyr : knyht was of gret honour,
Þat wuste seint laurence in prisone : þoru&yogh; heste of þe Aumperour,
And þoru&yogh;h him turnde to cristindom : and his maine al-so,
And burede him ful stilleliche : þo he was to deþe i-do.
¶ Þo he hadde seint laurence i-bured : and hit was vnder-&yogh;ite,
Men ortreuweden þat he cristine were : ase huy mi&yogh;hten wel þo i-wite.
Þene þridde day aftur : þat seint laurence i-bured was,
Ypolyt wende to is owene hous : ase it were bi cas;
Al his mayne he grette fayre : and &yogh;af heom part al-so
Of þe milsfole dede þat he hadde : on seint laurence i-do.
¶ his meyne, þat al cristine was : fair semblaunt him made i-nou&yogh;h,
And sone þo it time was : toward þe mete him drov&yogh;.
Þo þat bord was i-leid : and he was þarto i-sete,
And his mete bi-fore him i-brou&yogh;ht : er he hadde ou&yogh;t i-&yogh;ete,
Þe kny&yogh;htes comen in ate &yogh;ate : luþere men i-nowe,
bi-fore decius þe Aumperour : wel filliche him drowe.
¶ Þo decius i-sai&yogh;h him furst : a-busemare he lou&yogh;,
And seide : "ypolyt, hou gez þis? : turnste to þe wou&yogh;h?
honoure ore godes, ich [þe] rede : and do ore heste sone,
And do, ase þou art hiende kni&yogh;ht : ase þou au&yogh;test for-to done!"
¶ "Sire, ich habbe," quath ypolyt : "in folie longue i-beo
And in vnconnesse mi lijf i-leoued : ase man þat ne couþe ise;
Ake nouþe ich am to god i-turnd— : to late i dude so!
Þou do bi me al þat þou canst : for non oþur i-nelle do."
¶ "No? neltþou?" quat þis Aumperur : "þou schalt i-leue me,
Ase we serueden laurence er : we schullen nou serui þe!"
"&YOGH;e, god it[al. om.] &yogh;eue," quath þis holie man : "þat it were bi me nouþe
Ase it mid him is þat þou nemmest : ri&yogh;ht nouþe with luþere mouþe!"
¶ "Goz forth," quath þis Aumperour : "mine tormentores, a-non,
And streputh naked þis luþere þef : ri&yogh;ht to flechs and bon!"
Þis tormentores wel &yogh;are were : to don þat sorie dede.
Þe holie man, þo he was naked : to þe Aumperour he seide;
Þis holie man seide,[þis—seide al. om.] "wenstou, wrechche, to make me naked? : nay þou, i-wis,
Ake þou bi-guinnest raþur to cloþie me : with Ioye of heouene blis."
¶ "Nimez a-non," quath þe Aumperour : "and tormentiez him wel faste!"
Þe tormentores al redie weren : and heor cloþes of huy caste,
Wiþ scourges and with staues al-so : huy beoten him ase huy weren wode,
And al defouleden is holie bodi : þat is limes ronnen a-blode;
So longue, þat huy [werie] weren : and þare-fore stille huy stode.
Þe Aumperour bi-heold heom faste : with ful sorie mode.
¶ Þis holie man, þo him smert sore : lude to grede he gan :
"Ich þonki þe, louerd iesu crist : for ich am cristine man."
"Nimez him," quath þe Aumperour : "and ledez him up on hei&yogh;h!"
huy brou&yogh;hten him up-on an he[Ash. hei] de-grece : þat muche[al þat] folk him i-sei&yogh;h,
And duden on him is noble[on the margin.] robe : þat he werede er
Þe &yogh;wyle he was so noble kny&yogh;ht : and of so gret power.
¶ Þo he stod al-so quoynteliche : ase men him greþi mi&yogh;hte,
"Ypolyt," quath þe Aumperour : "nouþe þou hast þine ri&yogh;hte.
bi-þench þe wuch a man þou art : and &yogh;wuch a kny&yogh;ht[a k. om. in Ash.] þou hast i-beo,
Noble and hende, ase þou &yogh;uyt schalt : &yogh;if þou wolt þe bi-seo;
bi-þench þe of þat þou hast i-haued : of þi noble dignete,
And bi-lef here in ore compaynie : ase þou were er with me!"
¶ "Sire Aumperour," quath [þis] holie Man : "for nou&yogh;ht þou spext so :
For a newe kny&yogh;ht ich am bi-come : niewe batayle to do;
Godes kny&yogh;ht of heouene ich am : and al mi wille so is
Þat ich in his batayle be[Ash. were] : sone i-martred, i-wis."
Þo was þe Aumperour wroth i-nov&yogh;h : he cleopede Valerian,
his Iustise, þat was schrewe i-nov&yogh; : and a swiþe luþer man;
"Nim," he seide, "þis foule þef : and with a strong torment
bring him of liue, ase þou mi&yogh;ht : with hard Iuggement;
And wiend furst hom to is þingue : and nim al his guod,
For euerech del ich &yogh;iue it þe : and his flechs and his blod."
¶ To þis holie mannes hous : þe Iustise wende a-non,
Al his maynie he fond þare : cristine euerechon;
Ech aftur oþur he liet heom nime : and tormenti sore i-nov&yogh;;
And bi-fore þis holie man : ech aftur oþur drou&yogh;
And ech aftur oþur bi-fore his ei&yogh;ene : with gret torment he[Ash. me] slov&yogh; :
he liet alle heore hauedene smiten of : with schendnesse and wou&yogh;.
¶ Þo huy weren bi-fore þis holie man : alle to deþe i-brou&yogh;ht,
And þe Iustise i-sai&yogh;h þat he ne mi&yogh;hte : þare-with tuyrne is þou&yogh;ht,
wilde coltes and strongue : he liet fette atþe laste
And bi þe fet þisne holie man : to heore tayle he bond faste,
And liet þe coltes eorne forth. : wel luyte huy wolden a-bide,
Ake ornen and drowen þene holie Man : al-a-boute wel wide,
Þoru&yogh; scharpe breres and þornes : and ope manie an harde stone;
Þe peces fullen þicke a-boute : of his flesche fram þe bone.
So longue, þat he liet þat lif— : his deth was strong i-nov&yogh;,
&YOGH;wane ech of þis wilde coltes : at heore tayle him drov&yogh;!
¶ Ore louerd hat ofte for his loue : fair miracle i-do
On hors þat weren to him i-mete : and on coltes al-so.
Manie Men habbuth i-said þare-fore : &yogh;wane huy &yogh;eme to hors toke :
"Ore louerd and seint ypolyt : þis hors saue and loke!"
bidde we nouþe seint ypolyt : þat he ore erinde beode,
Þat merci he[al. god] habbe of us alle : and off alle þat habbuth neode.[After the Saints' Lives, follow in MS. Laud: 68. Sayings of St. Bernard. 69. Vision of St. Paul (both ed. by me in Herrig's Archiv, 1874). 70. Debate of body and soul. 71. Havelok. 72. King Horn (ed. in Herrig's Archiv, 1873); after this, 3 more legends written by a later hand, of which I add two in the Appendix.]
